boat.full_description:
The Zyclon 4-tonner named Zephon, was found in Penryn, close to Falmouth firmly supported by beaching legs. Her cockpit was not covered and not self-draining so there was some water in the bilge but other than that she looked pretty healthy when we arrived at low tide

During the night rain fell in abundance and Zephon’s bilge was filled again with rainwater. No salty taste, so the hull was watertight. A superficial inspection of the hull gave me confidence that she could be sailed home to Holland. I saw 9 broken frames, but she was built sturdily enough.

The deck didn’t leak. Too bad that it was covered with polyester which sounded, moving around on it, like walking on a freshly laid shell path.

The hatches were in a bad condition and leaked and the cockpit was a shambles of loose planks.

Somebody at one time started rebuilding the interior of reclaimed timber.

The previous owner had removed the engine and dismounted the shaft tube and plugged the hole.

Even so, Zephon looked healthy and, after all, I was looking for a restoration that I could be proud of.

Once home again, negotiations started resulting in a good deal. Everybody happy!

My plan was to spend a week preparing the boat to make her ready to sail to Holland without an engine. My friends convinced me that this was not a very good idea so I considered to use an outboard engine instead. This had been tried by the previous owner; it didn’t work well, the propeller came out of the water trying to make itself useful as a windmill or the whole engine taking a dive disappearing from sight. So, in the end I started looking out for a used 10 hp Yanmar inboard engine.

On our way

My car was fully loaded with a used Yanmar, spare parts, tools and friends Han and Roos and we set out to drive to Penryn.

Han and I would prepare the boat for the trip to Holland and Rose would drive the car back to Holland. Han postponed his decision to sail along as a crew member or not depending on his final analysis of risks involved.

Instead of lifting Zephon out of the water (too expensive: £400) , we decided to transport the engine by dinghy and hoist it on board using the boom and main sail sheet. Piece of cake. We struggled through thick mud at low tide, dismounted the disk covering the propeller tube hole, unplugged the hole from the inside and shoved in the propeller tube accompanied with lots of kit and then the propeller shaft with propeller. We finished the job off by squeezing in lots of lubrication grease and waited for high tide to see wether or not we had to call the fire brigade.

Everything stayed watertight. Time for a beer on the harbor quay.

The previous owner, Giles Gilmore, was out of the country but helped us tremendously by asking his girlfriend to put her apartment at our disposal. Fantastic to be able to take a hot shower after all the mud, the blood and no beer , than finally we had some British ale ,and slept in a real bed.

Back on board of Zephon we had to install Yanmar somewhat more aft than where the dismantled engine had been, which meant that part of the bridge deck had to be demolished.

Most work involved driving back and forth to local stores to score English fittings to match European hose sizes or discovering that the engine flange was 1 inch, not 25 mm.

The 3rd day the engine was running and Zephon could be further prepared for the high seas.

Our first few meters with Zephon were hilarious.

We sailed to a harbour in Falmouth, Han at the helm, Rose busying herself with mooring lines and fenders.

I had positioned myself in the “engine room” shifting gears from forwards to reverse and vice versa because of the lack of a morse handel handle.

I wasn’t very good at this could and could not hear Han shouting. ,we found out that it wasn’t easy to properly steer Zephon, she ,being a boat where the propeller shaft is positioned off-center and does not give any pressure on the rudder blade.

Rose left to visit her relatives and Han stayed to share in our adventurous undertaking.

The weather did not cooperate ,and with a stiff north easterly wind we, hard core pensioners sailing an unfamiliar 6 m short boat, experienced tough circumstances in a wild, rough sea.

We left Falmouth together with a Dutch, pitch black J-class yacht. She did her best to look like a submarine, waves running over deck. Very soon they let the sails down, started the engine and returned to Falmouth. That provided us the excuse, without loosing face, to return to St. Just creek, a magnificent spot where, unfortunately, I lost my wallet while hoisting a mooring buoy on board.

For those having aspirations to dive for a fortune, I lost it close to buoy C16. It lies approximately 10 feet deep and contains enough quid to get drunk in the pub.

We scraped our dutch courage together and left next day again.

At Dodman Point’s our foresail was torn apart. We considered to turn around profiting from the backstay wind or round this cape using mainsail and jib only. This worked and without any further damage we arrived in Fowey harbor. Too bad we were at leeward shore with lots of wind; we could have made it to Mevagissey or Charlestown if conditions had been better.

Part of the purchase deal was a typical, sturdy British dinghy; Han thought we shouldn’t leave her behind so we towed her behind Zephon. This worked out quite well except when the sea was rough and she overtook us by planing on the waves to be stopped abruptly by the towing line. She even tried to jump on board several times which started to irritate us, but after having taken care of her so many miles we became a little attached to our baby. The best remedy to keep her in check was to incorporate 2 rubber shock absorbers in the towing line close to the dinghy.

In Studland Bay we decided to try out our beaching legs. We cleaned up her bottom and had a good look at her from a distance. She is a peculiar boat, you like her or you don’t, but she is certainly a remarkable appearance.

We climbed up the hill to find a nice pub to enjoy a good healthy bar meal. To our amazement 2 other old men arrived to have a beer or two and their meal but still wearing their life vests 200 meters above sea level.

In Shoreham we beached the boat again, this time not using the legs; not on purpose, we left our bunks just a little too late. We spent 4 hours anxiously waiting for the boat, with her eyes below water, to reluctantly stand upright again.

From here on the lack of wind coming from the northeast made us use the engine a lot and we made good progress. Such good progress that we decided to spend a day in Oostende.

We stayed for 2 days, as the wind had shifted to SW and had increased to Bft 6-7, not particularly ideal conditions for a little, 6 meter long boat. But to be honest, the Belgian beer was not bad either.

We were lucky to find MFV “Border Maid” willing to take our dinghy along to Haarlem.

We were freed from our child and happily concluded the final miles to Holland with a genuine Belgian hangover.

All in all we had a nice sailing trip of about 1500 nm of which some 1000 up and down and the remainder horizontally.

Zephon sails very nicely in smooth water and steers itself, sometimes running more than 5 kts.

We experienced rough seas frequently, slowing us down considerably.

The engine made us reach a speed of 2,5-3 kts. Not very fast. We went backwards with the engine in forward gear when rounding Portland Bill; the current was too much for our little engine.

My theory to explain the engine’s misbehavior is that the propeller’s pitch does not match the reduction of the gear box.

Zephon frequently aroused enthusiastic and compassionate reactions. She was photographed for instance, resting on her beaching legs, by Mike, an Englishman, who found us in the local pub to exchange addresses so he could send us the pictures.

In Scheveningen somebody knocked on the hatch. He brought us a couple of Prestige beers. Sailors who visit Scheveningen harbor with such a beauty deserve to be treated on a beer. How about that?

Zephon arrived safely in Enkhuizen in 2019, ready to undergo a proper refit over the winter. She was sailing again, fully repaired in 2021.

Where does this peculiar name come from?

Harrison Butler asked his customers that bought a design from him to choose a name for the boat starting out with the letter of the particular type. In Zephon’s case the Z of Zyclon.

After bringing her to Enkhuizen I googled the meaning of Zephon. He (not she) was an angel guarding paradise described in the Hebrew bible.

In retrospect, I am sure that our trip with a boat named after the “Guardian of Paradise” could not have gone wrong at all

Fred Schotman
boat.name: Zephon
boat.short_description: Zephon is now based in the Netherlands
